case_vignette: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever, weakness, diffuse abdominal pain, and multiple lumps on his body. He has recently returned to the USA from a 3-month agricultural internship in South America. Physical examination shows enlarged superficial cervical and inguinal lymph nodes. There is tender hepatomegaly. A photomicrograph of a liver biopsy sample after methenamine silver staining is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Tick-borne illnesses can cause a range of symptoms including fever, weakness, and swollen lymph nodes. They can also cause joint pain, muscle aches, and fatigue. Some tick-borne illnesses, such as Lyme disease, can also cause a distinctive rash or ring-shaped rash around the site of the tick bite.

It's important to note that tick-borne illnesses can be difficult to diagnose and can mimic other conditions. A thorough medical evaluation and laboratory testing are needed to confirm the diagnosis.

I would recommend that you consult with a healthcare provider as soon as possible to discuss your symptoms and recent travel history. They can perform the necessary tests and evaluations to determine the cause of your symptoms and provide appropriate treatment.
